summary.seg: The Book of Cerne is a prayerbook made in Mercia, probably in the 820s. It is one of the most interesting and least famous of early Anglo-Saxon illuminated manuscripts, over-shadowed by the compelling presence of the great Insular gospel books, bibles and psalters and by the prodigious works of Bede and Aldhelm. Yet this complex and visually attractive book, and its relationships with other artefacts of its period, cast a strong beam of light upon the history and culture of its age and upon the kingdom of Mercia.

The sobriquet 'The Book of Cerne' stems from the book's later medieval provenance, for the 9th-century manuscript is now sandwiched between two lengthy sequences of documentary and liturgical materials from the monastery of Cerne Abbas in Dorset. These date from the 14th to the 16th century and are unlikely to have been added to the manuscript during the Middle Ages, and possibly not until after 1697 (when the manuscript was recorded in the possession of John Moore, with only the copy of the Magna Carta noted in addition to the 9th-century contents). Codicological evidence of previous bindings furthermore indicates that the 9th-century portion was probably bound independently of other materials during the medieval period. We cannot be sure when the Anglo-Saxon book reached the Benedictine Cerne Abbey, which was founded (or perhaps refounded) in 987 by Æthelmær the Stout, a leading thegn of King Æthelred and ealdorman of the Western Provinces. He was the patron of the famous homilist Ælfric of Eynsham, who became a priest at Cerne and taught there. Might this prayerbook have reached Cerne as part of Ælfric's devotional books, or through Æthelmær?

Whatever its later ownership, internal evidence points to the Book of Cerne having been made as the personal prayerbook of Bishop Æthelwald of Lichfield (818-830). It contains an abbreviated psalter that has previously been attributed to Bishop Æthilwald of Lindisfarne (722-740), since it is introduced by a now almost illegible rubric in Latin: 'hoc argumentum forsorum [sic. versorum] oeðelpald episcopus decrepsit' ('Bishop Ædeluald has worn out these lines of proof'); see f. 2:87v). This may refer to his priestly diligence in being 'psalteratus': that is, able to recite the Psalms by heart. There is also an acrostic poem on f. 2:21r, written in lines of several alternating colours, some of which are now very faded and difficult to read with the naked eye. The first letters of each line read (vertically) 'AEDELVALD EPISCOPUS'. David Dumville argued that both occurrences indicate that the manuscript was wholly or in part a copy of one made a century earlier on Holy Island in Northumbria. However, the spelling of Æthelwald's name uses the Mercian 'el' rather than the Northumbrian 'il' for the second syllable. I have proposed instead that, rather than being a direct copy, the manuscript was a 9th-century compilation which drew upon earlier materials from various sources, including 8th-century Northumbria.

Cerne is one of a group of four Mercian prayerbooks, the others being:
London, British Library, Harley MS 7653 ('The Harleian Prayerbook')
London, British Library, Harley MS 2965 ('The Book of Nunnaminster')
London, British Library, Royal MS 2.A.xx ('The Royal Prayerbook') They are the first such books, before the advent of Books of Hours in the 13th century, in which their contents are arranged thematically as a protracted devotional meditation. These comprise extracts from the Gospels followed by a selection of prayers, hymns and charms - and, in Cerne's case, the breviate Psalter, Harrowing of Hell and acrostic poem, plus four evangelist miniatures prefacing its four Passion narratives from the Gospels. However, there are notable differences. Whereas the three British Library manuscripts contain linguistic and provenance evidence that points to them having been made by and probably for women, Cerne – the latest and most developed member of the group – was made for a man. There is also a slightly varying focus in each example. The Book of Nunnaminster takes salvation as its theme, while the Royal Prayerbook's focus is on Christ as the physical and spiritual health of humankind and tends to select miracles of healing in its Gospel extracts that relate to women. The Harleian Prayerbook is very fragmentary but still reveals some grammatical features indicating the female voice, like the other two, and similar Mercian set minuscule script and little decorated or zoomorphic initials.

The theme of the Book of Cerne, meanwhile, revolves around the Communio Sanctorum (Communion of Saints): the body of the Church comprising those on earth (the Church Militant), those awaiting resurrection (the Church Expectant) and those already in heaven (the Church Triumphant), with Christ as its head. There is a preface in Old English – one of the earliest pieces of English vernacular prose – which instructs the bishop on how to use the book, prostrating himself before the Communion of Saints each day and reciting it, in order to reinforce his place within it. Another unusual text in Cerne is a responsorial Harrowing of Hell, which recounts how Christ freed all those already languishing in hell on Easter Saturday. This takes the form of spoken dialogue between Adam and Eve and has led to the suggestion that it represents the first known text of a piece of liturgical drama, which may also have originated in Lindisfarne. The Harrowing of Hell text extends the message of Christ's salvific mission to those who had been languishing in hell, and the breviate Psalter links them all in prayer with those already in heaven. The Psalter was the mainstay of both public liturgical, communal monastic and individual private prayer. It is complemented by the suite of prayers and hymns that follow the Gospel extracts. Thus each of the parts of the Communio Sanctorum are unified and united under Christ, the head of the body of the Church and Bishop Æthelwald of Lichfield reaffirmed his own place in that communion when he performed his own devotions with his prayerbook – a much more sophisticated compilation that the usual florilegia or pamphlets of prayers otherwise encountered before the high Middle Ages.

At the beginning of each Gospel's Passion narrative, a miniature of the relevant evangelist faces the text page, where an elaborate decorated initial and coloured display script are used for the opening words. In each of these miniatures, a full-length 'terrestrial' evangelist symbol is set within an architectural arcade at the apex of which is a roundel containing a half-length human bust of each evangelist. These are clean shaven, long-haired and slightly effete, whilst the symbols are robust and slightly naïve in style (other than the strong graphic design of the eagle). The bull is a full-length adaptation of the half-length one seen in the St Augustine Gospels (Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 286, f. 129v), the famous Gospels thought to have accompanied St Augustine to Canterbury from Rome in 597. The figure style and the palette, with its distinctive slate grey/blue and brick-red/brown alongside its yellow, red, blue, white and purples may seem somewhat provincial, but costly powdered gold is also used in the initials and display panels of the Gospel incipits. These also feature iconographic messaging: for example, the St Matthew initial features a 'manticore' – the half lion, half-human harbinger of death in the Physiologus – announcing the Passion of Christ.

It is the Latin inscriptions in display capitals that accompany the busts and symbols of the evangelists, however, that really give the clue to the sophistication of this manuscript. They announce the busts of the evangelists – 'Here is Matthew [/Mark/Luke/John] in his human guise' – and then describe their symbols in distinctive terms that perform a hypertextual and intertextual function by alluding to the phraseology of relevant passages in the Gospels. For example, Luke's inscription reads 'Hic Lucas formam accepit uituli' ('Here Luke accepts the form of a calf/bull'), which would remind informed readers of one of the key Easter readings from Phillipians 2:7: 'Rather, he made himself nothing by taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness'. As Gregory the Great and Bede both wrote, the sacrificial calf or bull of St Luke symbolises the crucified servant Christ. These exegetical interpretations are also pursued in the other evangelist miniatures. Each recalls the practice of explaining the different yet complementary character of each Gospel, and of its symbolism of different facets of Christ's persona and mission, with the aid of visual images during the 'Apertio aurium'. This was the practice by which adult baptismal candidates were instructed in the forty days leading up to Easter, at which point they would be baptised and enter the Communion of Saints to serve God in the world as a member of the Church Militant.

The prayers – all in Latin – open with an initial and display panel akin to the Gospel extract openings, and thereafter each prayer begins with a decorated initial, many featuring bird or animal heads. The first text is the Lorica of Laidcenn / Loding, an Irish prince, and it is accompanied by its original interlinear Old English gloss. As with the Preface, this bears witness to Mercia's espousal of the written vernacular before the ascendancy of Wessex and the Alfredian revival of religion and learning. Rather than declining, Mercia was embracing new cultural challenges during the first half of the 9th century, until Viking raids destroyed its ecclesiastical buildings and their libraries, and pushed these manuscripts westwards: the Royal Prayerbook to Cornwall, and Cerne and the Book of Nunnaminster to Wessex.

foliation.p: Unfortunately, the manuscript has been subjected to a series of attempts at foliation. With one, later exception, none of these attempts covered the manuscript as a whole: 9th-century core as well as the extraneous, later medieval leaves that enclose it. The first sequence to be added appears to be by the hand of Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886, who numbered the 9th-century leaves '2-98' (in pencil, in the top right-hand corner of the rectos). He assigned '1' to a leaf at the beginning that he judged to be missing (as per the foliation practice he established at Cambridge University Library). A later foliator numbered the extraneous leaves in two continuous sequences of Roman numerals: i-xxvi at the front and i-xxviii at the back. Subsequently, these were subdivided with letters A-F, apparently in order to demarcate codicological divisions between the added leaves. However, not every such division was captured by this intervention: compare the first and second leaves of 'C' with the third and forth. The likelihood is that whoever added these letters was following the quire numbers added in ink to the centre of the bottom margin by an 18th- or 19th-century hand. Furthermore, a haphazard change was then made to the Roman numeral foliation, restarting the sequence at each lettered division by overwriting the superceded numerals. This was done tentatively, however, with the cancellation being not always obvious. The only consistent and correct sequence are the Arabic numerals written in pencil, in the bottom right-hand corner of the recto side, probably during the 20th century. These are written continuously for the extraneous leaves, but only at intervals for the 9th-century core, which regrettably obstructs straightforward reference.

It is recognised that most scholarship has referred and will refer to foliation in the place where it is most commonly found in medieval manuscripts: that is, in the top right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf. In order to minimise the disruption to citations past and future, the decision has been made to follow the approach used in A.N. Doane, Anglo-Saxon Bibles and 'The Book of Cerne', Anglo-Saxon Manuscripts in Microfiche Facsimile, vol. 7 (Tempe, 2002). There, the manuscript is divided into three broad parts, as follows:
Part 1: a collection of bifolia and quires containing memoranda of documents relating to Cerne of various origins and dates
Part 2: the 9th-century prayer book
Part 3: the sequentiary Recognising the separate origins of the component sections of Parts 1 and 3, Doane subdivided these using letters, which will be followed here and prefixed to the foliation. This permits the continuous sequence of Roman numerals to be followed, while ensuring that the duplicated sequences at the front and rear are unique - necessary for the preparation of a digital catalogue description. Bradshaw's foliation will be retained for Part 2. The sequence as a whole will thus be:

collation.p: Reflecting the approach to dealing with the numbering of the leaves (on which, see Foliation), the summary collation statement given here distinguishes between the core, 9th-century manuscript (Part 2), and the later, added leaves at the beginning (Parts 1a-1f) and at the end (Part 3a-3b). Each of these additional Parts are dealt with separately in the catalogue descriptions that follow, reflecting the different circumstances of their production.
collation.signatures: Leaf signatures in typical alphanumeric form (ai-aiiii to mi-miiii) written in pencil in the bottom right-hand corner of the rectos in the first half of each quire in the 9th-century part of the manuscript only, by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886.

Quire numbers in Arabic numerals (1-20) written by an 18th-/19th-century hand in ink in the centre of the bottom margin of the recto side of the first leaf of each quire, across the later medieval additions and 9th-century core.

note.p: Sections of the manuscript marked 'A' to 'F', in pencil, in the centre of the top margin, by a 19th-/20th-century hand. See Foliation for further discussion.

binding.p: The manuscript has undergone several successive rebindings, encompassing the 9th-century core alone as well as with the later additions, and traces of their structure may be seen in the sewing patterns left on the leaves. For a diagrammatic illustration of these, see Brown (1996), p. 234.
Full goatskin binding by Sandy Cockerell Cockerell, Sydney Morris, 1962. A typescript summary of Cockerell's work in attached to the rear pastedown.

Bowtell-style quarter sheepskin binding with marbled paper-covered sides, late 18th-century. For a description of the make-up and condition of this binding upon its arrival at Grantchester for rebinding in 1962, see Brown (1996), p. 33. A spine label from this binding - reading 'MAGNA CARTA ETC. M.S.' - has been retained on the front pastedown. Although the microfiche that accompanies the description in Doane (2002) antedates the 1962 rebinding, neither the exterior nor interior of the covers was captured.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 113 (f. 1:i recto) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the front pastedown.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the descriptions prepared for: Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press); Anglo-Saxon Manuscripts in Microfiche Facsimile (1994-), vol. 7: A.N. Doane, Anglo-Saxon bibles and 'The Book of Cerne' (Tempe: Arizona Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, 2002); and Michelle P. Brown, The Book of Cerne: prayer, patronage and power in ninth-century England (London: British Library, 1996). Further, detailed bibliographies are also provided therein.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.custEvent: The manuscript was on display in the British Library exhibition Anglo-Saxon Kingdoms: Art, Word, War, 19 October 2018-19 February 2019.

msItem.title: Memoranda of grants of indulgences to those giving gifts to Cerne Abbey

msItem.title: Acknowledgement from Robert, Abbot of Cerne, of feudal obligations due to Henry II and Henry III

p.seg: Single column, 26-32 lines to the page (this, and dimensions, not including the added memorandum on f. 1:i verso).

handNote.p: Mainly written by a single mid-14th-century hand, in anglicana. Additions by two other hands also writing in Anglicana on f. 1:i verso and 1:ii verso.

decoNote.p: Plain initials in brown ink, at the opening of some of the documents on f. 1:ii recto.

binding.p: Damage in the form of a friction hole, positioned at the mid-point of the fore-edge margin, suggestive of the presence of a single clasp in a previous binding, not shared by the other late-medieval additions.

msItem.title: Missal [extract]
msItem.note: Prayer for the Introit of the Mass 'Oratio beati augustini aurelii ante missam dicenda: Summe sacerdos et uere pontifex qui te optuilisto deo patri hostiam puram'

msItem.title: Settlement of a land dispute between Cerne and St Swithin's, Winchester, 33 Henry III [1249]
Two forms of request from monks of Cerne to Henry III for permission to elect a new abbot
msItem.note: Lines 1-15. Undated.

msItem.title: Two forms of request from monks of Cerne to Pandulf, bishop-elect of Norwich, to intercede with Henry III to allow the election of a new abbot
msItem.note: Line 16 on f. 1f:xxiv recto to line 13 on f. 1f:xxiv verso. Undated. Pandulf was elected between 18 July and 9 August 1215, and reigned as bishop of Norwich 1215-1226, but was not consecrated until 29 May 1222.

msItem.title: Nomination by monks of Cerne of electors of a new abbot
msItem.note: Lines 1-11.

msItem.title: Further notices concerning land disputes between Cerne and St Swithin's, Winchester
msItem.note: Lines 14-20 on f. 1f:xxiv verso and lines 12-21 on f. 1f:xxv recto. 'On f. 23b we find a copy of a final judgement between the Abbot of Cerne and the Prior of St Swithin of Winchester in 33 Henry III: on f. 24b comes an undated notes of the plea commencing the action: then on f. 25a a note of an alleged inconsistency between the present claim of the Prior and his claim in some previous litigation: and lastly on ff. 25b-26v notes of the proceedings in such earlier litigation...' (see Lock (1908), p. 222).

msItem.title: Collection of various notices of actions in county court concerning Cerne

supportDesc.condition: Pages mutilated and of uneven sizes and trim, several repaired on edges with parchment inlay (which have been mutilated in turn).

p.seg: Frame and line ruling, hardpoint, single column, 20-21 lines to the page (f. 1f:xxi rescored; f. 1f:xxiv has additional ruling for 24 lines). Layout for the missal extract largely followed by subsequent documentary texts.

handNote.p: Missal written by a hand of the second half of the 13th/early 14th century, in textualis.
Documentary texts copied by four hands of similar date, all in textualis (see Doane (2002) for further discussion).

decoNote.p: Plain initials in red, two-lines at the opening and one-line thereafter, in the missal extract.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 13th or early 14th century.

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio cui omnia subiecta sunt'
msItem.incipit: 2:79r: Deus meus et pater et filius et spiritus sanctus. Cui omnis creatura deseruit et omnis potestas subiecta est

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio sancti a Petri Apostoli'
msItem.incipit: 2:79r: Domine deus omnipotens. Qui sedis super cherubin. et profundum Abyssi Intueris. Ad te leuamus maus nostras In similtudinem crucis tuae

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio ad Sanctum Petrum'
msItem.incipit: 2:79v: Sancte petre Apostole te supplex quaesso Ut me indignum adiuues. tuis orationibus
msItem.note: 'me' altered from 'mihi', 'indignum' from 'indigne', both by a later hand.

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio ad Sanctum Petrum'
msItem.incipit: 2:80r: Quaeso te sancte apostole domini nostri iesu christi. Qui uocatus nomine petrus. Qui super fundamentum eius aedificasti ecclesiam domini

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio ad Sanctum Petrum'
msItem.incipit: 2:80v: Rogo te beate petre princeps Apostolorum et clauicularius regni caelestis
msItem.note: Rubric traced over in red ink by a later hand.

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio ad Sanctum Andream Apostolum'
msItem.incipit: 2:80v: Salue sancta crux quae in corpore christi dedicata es. et ex membris eius tamquam margaritis ornata

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio ad Sanctum Andream Apostolum'
msItem.incipit: 2:81r: O Andreas sancte pro me intercede Ut euadam purae flammas durae poenae. Te nunc peto care mane Atque nocte

msItem.title: Prayer 'Commoniter ad apostolos'
msItem.incipit: 2:81v: Teto petri pastoris praesidia. et iacobi iusti adiutoria. Andreae quoque optimi egregia
msItem.note: For 'Teto' read 'Peto'.

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio de Apostolis Sanctis Domini nostri Iesu Christi'
msItem.rubric: 2:82r: Oratio de apostolis sanctis domini nostri iesu [christi]
msItem.incipit: 2:82r: Domine iesu christe qui dedisti potestatem apostolis tuis. Infirmos curare. Mortuos suscitare. Leprosos mundare ... per uerbum eorum In me
msItem.note: It is unclear whether the last word of the rubric was ever written or has faded.
'ut omnes unum sint sicut tu pater in me. et ego in te ut et ipsi in nobis unum sint ... et gloria in saecula saeculorum. amen': nine lines added by a later hand at the end of the prayer.

msItem.title: Hymn 'Ymnum super Euangelium Christi et oratio Sancti Hieronimi et Paulini
msItem.rubric: 2:84r: Ymnum Super euangelium christi et oratio sancti hieronimi et paulini
msItem.incipit: 2:84r: Ymnum dicat turba fratrum ymnum cantus personat christo regi concinnantes laudem demus debitam. Te dei de corde uerbum tu uia tu ueritas iesse uirga

msItem.title: Hymn 'Ymnum de Apostolis Sanctis Domini nostri Iesu Christi'
msItem.rubric: 2:85r: Ymnum de apostolis sanctis domini nostri iesu christi
msItem.incipit: 2:84r: Luce uidet chrsitum quem petrus nocte negauit. et cernit dominum pergere ad astra suum

msItem.title: Hymn 'Ymnum pro peccatis'
msItem.incipit: 2:86r: Pro peccatis amare me nunc oportet flere. Ne me conburant dirae flammae profundae paene

msItem.title: Prayer 'Oratio commoniter'
msItem.incipit: 2:86v: Domine deus iesu uia uita ac ueritas aeternae uitae petimus Ut nos consortes facias

msItem.title: Hymn 'Ymnum de uirginibus'
msItem.incipit: 2:87r: Amici nobiles christe sunt uirgines regnant perpetuo cum ipso domino

msItem.title: Psalter [abbreviated]
msItem.rubric: 2:87v: hoc argumentum forsorum oeðlwald episcopus decerpsit
msItem.incipit: 2:87r: Beatus uir qui non abiit in consilio impiorum
msItem.note: In the rubric, read 'versorum' for 'forsorum'. The rubric is almost completely illegible. Worm-like creatures throughout the text mark runovers from the higher line to the right of the lower.

msItem.title: Harrowing of Hell
msItem.rubric: 2:98v: hoc est oratio innumerabilis sanctorum qui tenebantur in inferno captiuitate lacrimabili uoce et obsecratione saluatorem deposcunt dicentes quando ad infero discendit
msItem.incipit: 2:98v: Aduenisti redemptor mundi. Aduenisti quem desiderantes cotidie
msItem.rubric: 2:99r: Innumerabilium captiuorum Postquam autem audita est postulatio et obsecratio
msItem.incipit: 2:99r: Statim iubente domino omnes antiqui iusti sine alique mora
msItem.rubric: 2:99r: Adam autem et eua. ad hun non sunt desoluti de uinculis
msItem.incipit: 2:99r: Tunc adam lugubri ac miserabili uoce clamabat ad dominum dicens. Miserere mei deus
msItem.rubric: 2:99v: Tunc domino miserante adam e uinculis resolutis domini iesu christi genibus prouolutus
msItem.incipit: 2:99v: Benedic anima mea dominum
msItem.rubric: 2:99v: Adhuc eua persistit in fletu dicens
msItem.incipit: 2:99v: Iustus es domine et rectum Iudicium tuum
msItem.note: Largely a collection of excerpts from the Psalms (ending imperfectly).
Kuypers' l. 8, p. 198 is not evident in the manuscript.

collation.p:
Quires of eight leaves, with one exception (Quire 12), and losses or insertions elsewhere. The darkened condition of f. 2:2r suggests that the first leaf of Quire 7 was lost at an early date and that this leaf went uncovered for some time. The outside of f. 2:99v is also darkened, but to a lesser extent. Probably at least one quire has been lost after Quire 18. Diagrams of the structure of each 9th-century quire (7-18 numbered I-XII) are provided by Brown (1996), p. 233, and accord with the collation given here.
Quire 78-1 (ff. 2:2-2:8: 1st leaf, f. 1, missing)
Quire 88 (ff. 2:9-2:16)
Quire 98+1 (ff. 2:17-2:25: 5th leaf, f. 21, inserted)
Quires 10-118 (ff. 2:26-2:41)
Quire 1210 (ff. 2:42-2:51)
Quire 13-188 (ff. 2:52-2:99)

signatures.p: Original quire signatures (probably contemporary with the main text) at the bottom of the last verso of each quire, beginning with 'c' (f. 2:25v). Continues in sequence to 'l' (f. 2:91v) and 'm' (now faded, above the 'e' of 'tuae' in the last line of text, f. 2:99v). The first two quires appear to lack signatures, but the series implies that no quires are missing from the beginning of the 9th-century book.

p.seg: Frame and line ruling, hardpoint, single column, 18-20 lines to the page (ff. 2:2-2:47, usually 18 lines; ff. 2:48-75, 19 lines; ff. 2:76-2:91, 20 lines; ff. 2:92-2:99, 18 lines).

handNote.p: Main text (incl. Old English text on f. 2:2r and the acrostic poem on f. 2:21r) written by a single hand in 'elegant Southumbria pointed Insular minuscule'. See Doane (2002) for further details, notes on correcting hands, and references.

decoNote.p:
Full-page miniatures of the four evangelists. Pages prepared with straightedge and compass. Painted in slate blue, red, brown, yellow and white, with frames surrounded by red dots and decorated with floral motifs and head-masks. Inscriptions identify each evangelist in his human (above) and symbolic (below) form. Brown suggests that the programme of miniatures is ambitious and eclectic, but inexpertly executed, perhaps by several hands (see Brown (1996), pp. 72-115, for full discussion).
f. 2:2v St Matthew and angel: +HIC MATHEVS IN HVMANITATE. +HIC MATHEVS IN ANGELICA ASSPECTV VIDETUR
f. 2:12v St Mark and lion: +HIC MARCVS IN HVMANITATE. HIC MARCVS IMAGINEM TENET LEONIS
f. 2:21v St Luke and ox: +HIC LVCAS IN HVMANITATE. HIC LVCAS FORMAM ACCEPIT VITVLI
f. 2:31v St John and eagle: +HIC IOHANNIS [sic] IN HVMANITATE. HIC IOHANNIS VERTIT FRONTEM IN AQVILAM
Incipit bars: capitals in various combinations of colours, on coloured grounds and with a yellow border, featuring internal and external dotted decoration.

Four powdered gold initials, four to eight lines, decorated with interlace infill, zoomorphic and floral motifs, at beginning of Gospel Passion narratives: Et ligature (f. 2:3r), E (f. 2:13r), A (f. 2:22r), H (f. 2:32r).

Eighty-four large decorated coloured initials, two to four lines, (blue and yellow predominating), with interlace, curvilinear and zoomorphic ornaments (see, for example, ff. 2:11r, 2:19v, 2:28v, 2:40v, 2:42r, etc).
Initials in black ink, touched with various colours and often decorated.
Worm-like figures on ff. 2:87v-2:98r, interacting with letter forms and marking where the text runs over from one line to the next.
Titles and rubrics in red lead, with dashes and dots, many of which have now faded to a light yellowish white that is difficult or impossible to read under ordinary light.
'Elaborate programmatic coloured script decorations, by the same hand (see Brown (1996), pp. 65-67).
Abbreviation signs often touched with yellow.

note.p: Old English interlinear glosses on ff. 2:43r-2:44v, 10th-century. Another hand probably of the later 10th century has added Old English glosses to f. 2:57r.
Sketches in ink, in imitation of three of the evangelist portraits (ff. 2:2v, 2:21v, 2:31v) and a decorated initial (f. 2:72r, for 71v), and a floral design (f. 2:51v), all by a later hand or hands.

binding.p: Rust-stains on the upper and lower corners of the fore-edge margin on ff. 2:3-2:4 may indicate cornerpieces, bosses or clasps from a former binding specific to this 9th-century part (since the dmaage is not found on the preceding leaves.

origin.p: Manuscript dated to 818×830 on the basis of the acrostic poem. See Introduction and P.R. Robinson (1988), no. 73.

provenance.p: Perhaps owned and presumably made for Æthelwald, -830Æthelwald (d. 830), bishop of Lichfield, 818-830, on the basis of the acrostic poem on f. 2:21r and rubric on f. 2:87v. See Introduction, Brown (1996) and Dumville (1972) for further discussion.

Plain initials, alternating in red and brown (the ink of the main text), one line, throughout each sequence.

handNote.p: Written by several hands, in anglicana, secretary and a textualis bookhand.
